text:
Q: marginaleffects and future: global size exceeded A:

I think from future 1.4.0 you need to set the limit in the plan:

plan(multicore, workers = 8, maxSizeOfObjects = 10e9)

But I will wait for more knowledgeable persons to answer

Q: overscroll-behavior does not prevent browser navigation on gesture for overscroll except on html and body A:

It turned out the problem is a bug in Chromium and Webkit based browsers. It doesn't affect firefox.
The issues are https://issues.chromium.org/issues/41483088 and https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=240183 and can be voted on.

Indeed my original question it needed content and width but that wasn't what the issue was - I should have set up the example in the question better.

Q: How to align a bootstrap navbar toggle button to the left or right of the brand name? A:

You can use Media query and add margin on list items for only smaller screens.

Q: Update a value in a mapping table using SQL A:

@MatBailie's caught it already, but to clarify: your problem is that unknowingly, you're joining the target table to itself before joining the others, and that initial self-join is unqualified - all matches all. Remove it:

update person_map as pm
set active = false::boolean
  , updated_at = NOW()
from person_map pm --remove

join from fathers f on pm.father_id = f.id  --move to where
join mothers m on pm.mother_id = m.id
join siblings s on pm.sibling_id = s.id
join people p on pm.person_id = p.id

where
  pm.father_id = f.id  --how sources join to the target
  f.name = 'Jeff'
  m.name = 'Emy'
  s.name = 'Andy'
  p.name = 'Susan'
returning *;

or add a where to narrow it down:

update person_map as pm1
set active = false::boolean
  , updated_at = NOW()
from person_map as pm

join fathers f on pm.father_id = f.id
join mothers m on pm.mother_id = m.id
join siblings s on pm.sibling_id = s.id
join people p on pm.person_id = p.id

where
  pm.ctid=pm1.ctid --or some other, unique thing
  f.name = 'Jeff'
  m.name = 'Emy'
  s.name = 'Andy'
  p.name = 'Susan'
returning *;

In your case, the self-join doesn't help anything, so you're better off without it.

As to testing/debugging, you can make this a select, or you can wrap it in begin;..rollback; transaction and append returning *; to the update statement to see what it ended up doing.

ctid is a hidden system column you always have, uniquely identifying rows so you can use it if you have no other unique column in place. It's only guaranteed to stay consistent throughout a single query, so it's not a replacement for a proper primary key.

If you posted this as an actual question, not a best practices question, you'd be immediately pointed to a large body of duplicate threads here. The update x..from x.. seems to be a fairly common mistake.

Q: Android Studio “Agent” (Gemini Assistant) showing weird symbols in code blocks A:

It looks like a rendering/font fallback bug in the Gemini “Agent” panel, not a data/encoding problem in the JSON.

It can be a guessing way:
1. File → Invalidate Caches / Restart and choose Invalidate and Restart. (If nothing - moving on).
2. Open Help → Edit Custom VM Options → add "-Dide.browser.jcef.gpu.disable=true" in the end. → restart → check JSON rendering again. (If nothing - moving on, again)
3. Close Studio and clear JCEF cache → restart & try again
4 Even if you use custom fonts it can affect as an advice here are "4 NO" that good to check:
- No hidden IDE property for “Agent font”
- No theme-level override for tool-window fonts
- No per-plugin font config for Gemini
- No JSON/encoding issue in your data

Q: how to pass data to MaterialAlertDialogBuilder in android A:

Instead of

dialog.findViewById<EditText>(R.id.id1)?.text

use

dialog.findViewById<EditText>(R.id.id1)?.setText("Your data")

I know, it's clumsy API, but it's all we have.

Opposite way is also clumsy - to get text from TextEditor:

val taskText = txtTask.text.toString()
